Award.AwardTitle: Digitization PEN: Facilitating a Shared Image Library and Occurrence Database for Ants of the Southwest as Part of the SCAN TCN
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to complement the Southwest Collections of Arthropods Network (SCAN) Thematic Collection Network (TCN). SCAN is a collaborative of museums that pool their resources and digitize information for all their specimens of ground-dwelling insects and close relatives. The Museum of Comparative Zoology (MCZ) at Harvard will partner with SCAN and contribute world-renowned expertise in the identification and digitization of ants. Digital records of the some 90,000 specimens of ants from the American Southwest, including the type specimens (individual ants from which species have been described), will be imaged, digitized and made available on line. The project will be of value both to scientists studying biodiversity and the responses of ant species to climate change in the Southwest, and to non-scientists seeking to identify their species.

The broader impacts of this project will focus on the Navajo Nation, where researchers from the MCZ with Navajo scientists and student interns, have already collected more than 15,000 ants. Additional material to be developed with help from educators involved in Encyclopedia of Life (EOL) will include a local field guide to the ants. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Entomology Department of the Museum of Comparative Zoology (MCZ) has contributed to the Southwest Collections of Arthropods Network (SCAN) Thematic Collection Network (TCN) by expanding and upgrading the representation of ants (a SCAN focal group) from the southwestern USA.  To do this, researchers at Harvard developed an online image library of Formicidae from the southwestern states (AZ, UT, CO, NM) to facilitate identification of ants, especially those in the collections of the SCAN TCN.  This included high- resolution images of 221 (173 primary and 68 secondary) MCZ type specimens of ants from the American Southwest that were databased, geo-referenced, photographed and barcoded. Images for a total of 368 exemplar taxa were annotated with more detailed pictures of diagnostic characters used in preparing identification keys.  The MCZ supplemented this image library with occurrence data for approximately 68700 ant colonies from ants known to occur in the American Southwest.  Of these, 23168 were further documented with field notes regarding behavior and habitat preferences by Assistant Curator Stefan P. Cover. Digital collection records for these 68700 ant specimens contributed significantly to ant data gathered by the SCAN project, and assisted the long term goal of enhancing our understanding of biodiversity in the American Southwest, and thereby helping to guide conservation strategies in the face of climate change. 

The image library and enlarged database of collection records produced by this research are resources available to SCAN and to the general public, and the creation of these resources involved the training of graduate students, undergraduates and volunteers in museum databasing and curation. Additional broader impacts of this project focused on the Navajo Reservation, a sovereign region comprising over 30,000 square miles located in the heart of the American Southwest.  A further 3893 records of ant colonies collected on the reservation were documented, and this information was used to prepare a downloadable Field Guide and poster of the Ants of the Navajo Reservation.  These materials were discussed and distributed at 10 separate lectures delivered at schools and colleges throughout the Reservation by Navajo scientists Beverly Maxwell, a Master’s student at Northern Arizona University, and Evan Hoki, a graduate student at Harvard.
